head.title: -soliton formula and blowup result of the Wadati-Konno-Ichikawa equation
head.abstract: We formulate the soliton solution of the Wadati-Konno-Ichikawa equation that is determined by purely algebraic equations. Derivation is based on the matrix Riemann-Hilbert problem. We give examples of one soliton solution that include smooth soliton, bursting soliton, and loop type soliton. In addition, we give an explicit example for two soliton solution that blows up in a finite time.

outline._note:
The Wadati-Konno-Ichikawa (WKI) equation is given by where is a complex function on . Two different types of the WKI equations are first introduced in . The first type corresponds to , which is viewed as a nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) type equation, since the linearized operator of is the Schrödinger operator. Physically it is relevant to modelling the vortex filament in the low temperature regime. Recently, a formal derivation of the WKI equation is given in that follows from the Hamiltonian equation for a vortex line originally derived in . The WKI equation, being one of exotic soliton equations, admits a bursting soliton whose maximum hight is infinity. This was first shown by Shimizu and Wadati by the Gelfand-Levitan formulation to derive soliton solution. The construction relies on existence of a Lax operator whose eigenvalue appears as a nontrivial parameter of soliton solution. The WKI equation can be written in the form where is a solution to the Wadati-Konno-Ichikawa spectral problem, given by and where and \ It is shown in that the WKI spectral problem is related to the Ablowitz-Kaup-Newell-Segur (AKNS) type spectral problem under gauge transformations. This idea can be adapted for investigating auto-Bäcklund transformation, e.g., see .
Among other integrable equations associated with the WKI spectral problem, the Short-Pulse (SP) equation has been most extensively studied. The SP equation is related to the Sine-Gordon equation whose exact solutions are used to obtain exact solutions of the SP equation . Loop soliton and breather solutions of the SP equation have been studied in numerous literatures. Furthermore, a wave breaking result for the SP equation has been shown rigorously in . On the other hand, there has been little result on the WKI equation . From the fact that the WKI equation admits a bursting soliton, a naive question to ask is whether or not there exists a solution whose maximum hight blows up to infinity in a finite time. Existence of such blowup solution is not the case of many other integrable evolution equations. This question is interesting in problems of well-posedness and stability of soliton.
Recently, global dispersive solution to the WKI equation has been studied by one of us in , that is, if an initial data is smooth and small enough, then a corresponding solution remains smooth for all time. The matrix Riemann-Hilbert problem for the WKI spectral problem was formulated rigorously. In the present paper, we derive a fully algebraic formula of soliton solutions by summarizing a rigorous approach of the forward scattering problem and the inverse scattering problem which we relates to the framework of the matrix Riemann-Hilbert problem. The given formula, unarguably easier, will enable for further investigation into soliton behavior for the WKI equation. At present, we give a finite-time blowup soliton solution, i.e., the maximum hight of a smooth initial profile goes to infinity in a finite time. A blowup soliton is constructed in the case of two soliton case by MIXING a smooth soliton and a bursting soliton with suitably chosen parameters.
It is worth mentioning that the Gelfand-Levitan equation by Shimizu and Wadati could be extended to a soliton formula while an implicit equation (in our paper, it is expressed as an algebraic equation ) would remain to be non-algebraic and cumbersome to solve. Furthermore, their construction requires a potential to have a compact support. In our approach, this assumption can be significantly relaxed (see ). Additionally, we note that it is not clear how the Bäcklund transformation approach for the WKI equation leads to explicit soliton formula, while an idea of taking use of relation between the WKI system and the ANKS system is clear. Hence the Bäcklund transformation for the WKI equation requires further investigation.
It is well-known that the isotropic Heisenberg equation is related to the cubic NLS . This relation is written explicitly in equation (4.7) of . As mentioned previously, formally solution of the WKI equation is also related to the isotropic Heisenberg equation, explicitly written in equation (4.9) of by Wadati and Sogo. A simple and interesting question is, how does the WKI equation allow bursting solitons, while the isotropic Heisenberg equation and the cubic NLS are known not to have such explicit solutions? Unlike relation between the cubic NLS and the isotropic Heisenberg equation, solution of the WKI equation contains the inverse power of that of the isotropic Heisenberg equation. This latter relation is not well-defined. A singularity formation for the WKI equation appears to be quite possible.
The paper is organized as follows.
In Section \[soliton-derivation\], we give the algebraic formulas that give explicit solutions to the WKI equation.
In Section \[Riemann-Hilbert-section\], we summarize part of to give derivation of formulas introduced in Section \[soliton-derivation\]. there are mainly three important steps for technical aspects, (i) transformation of the WKI spectral problem to the ANKS spectral problem for existence and analyticity of the fundamental solutions, (ii) the change of spectral parameter for suitable normalization, (iii) the change of the spatial variable in that depends on the dependent variable to eliminate the potential in the jump condition of the Riemann-Hilbert problem. This type of transformation in (iii) is called the reciprocal transformation or the hodograph transformation in many literatures, e.g., see for integrable discretizations.
In Sections \[one-soliton-example\], we give three explicit examples of one soliton solutions, which are smooth soliton, bursting soliton, loop type soliton.
In Section \[two-soliton-example\], we consider two soliton solution with fixed spectral parameters which correspond to a smooth soliton and a bursting soliton, if they are considered individually in Section \[one-soliton-example\]. We give two different examples. One is that two soliton solution consists simply of smooth soliton and bursting soliton from initial time, as expected. The other is that the maximum hight of smooth two soliton at initial time blows up to infinity in a finite time. This example is shown in Subsection \[blowup-section\].

We denote as -soliton solution of the WKI equation. In order to derive , we will first obtain the intermediate solution, which is denoted as that depends on the spatial variable .
We denote sets of parameters and , where is the upper-half plane of the complex plane , and corresponds to the subscript of . We define by and we define by For example, we have that . We shall build matrices and using above notations, whose elements at the th row and the th column are given by We see that . Lastly, we define a vector , where is the th element in the vector.
Using the above notations, we introduce systems of algebraic equations for vector functions and , where is a identity matrix, is a vector with one in each entry.
The intermediate -soliton solution , defined on the variable , is found by the following formula where ’s are found in . The original variable is found from and is determined from the implicit function where are found in .
Finally, -soliton solution is obtained by and , where satisfies the implicit function .
To summarize the above presentation, initially we fix and follow the steps, given as where
Here, we summarize the results from . (There are a few notational changes for convenience.)

outline.text: Transformation to the AKNS type spectral problem
outline._note: We shall introduce the normalized solution to the WKI spectral problem and write the integral systems from , We use above to mean that is the normalized solution at . Instead of working with the integral equation directly, it is convenient to carry out the following transformations in the WKI spectral problem , where We note that and since is purely imaginary. We find that satisfy THE ANKS TYPE SPECTRAL PROBLEM, given as where

outline.text: Analytic properties of and scattering coefficients
outline._note:
We shall introduce the normalized solution by where Analytic properties of in the variable can be rigorously studied if for the ANKS type spectral problem (e.g, see Lemma 2.1 in ). Analyticities of are determined by those of since , is purely imaginary, and are independent of .
More precisely, we have where we denote as the th column of matrix , and as the upper/lower half planes of the -complex plane.
Furthermore, as in their domains of analyticity, we have
From , it follows that columns of shares the same analyticities as those of with the limits, and We define the scattering coefficients and by relations between and , where is a complex conjugate of . We see that can be written as the determinant which implies that is analytic in since and are analytic in .
The limit of as can be seen from and , so it follows that is analytic in with the limit

outline.text: The change in the spectral parameter
outline._note:
From and , we see that the matrix functions are not normalized to identity at , unlike that tend to as in their domains of analyticities. For this reason, we introduce the new spectral parameter We easily see that if and only if , which implies that where we use to denote the -complex plane. From the integral equation by introducing , as in their domains of analyticity. Furthermore, the integral equation gives that the potential is recovered from the derivative of the first term in the series that is,
Similarly, for in on the variable, we have that is analytic in , and the determinant form of in with the above asymptotic behavior gives for in the neighborhood of . To this end, we introduce the following sectionally meromorphic matrix function with (denote ) From the previous discussion, we see that are analytic in except at the possible zeros of and . The matrix function satisfy the following limits, from and , and from , , and , Furthermore, from , we can directly compute and verify that where we introduced the reflection coefficient . The condition is the jump condition for in on the real line. Smoothness and decay rate of depends on these of the potential . If has sufficient smoothness and decay rate, then is bounded and , and . It is important to note that at , is which coincides with the limit . This indicates the correct normalization in the form of defined in .
From , , and the fact that is analytic in except at zeros of , the matrix function in can be viewed as the solution of the normalized matrix Riemann-Hilbert (RH) problem. We have related the WKI spectral problem to the RH problem.
From , we shall give two important formulas that recover the potential . We denote as the th element of the matrix . We see that, from , one of important formulas is From , , and definition of , we have for in the neighborhood of , so the second important formula is given as

Up to this moment, we have not considered the time evolution of the WKI equation. Here we shall give a brief argument for the time evolution of reflection coefficient under the WKI time evolution .
Let be solution to the WKI equation. Taking in the Lax system with , we obtain . This implies that the fundamental solutions that satisfy the both Lax systems must take form of . Following the exactly same definition of the scattering coefficients and with in , we find We find that the reflection coefficient depends on as What follows is that we will simply replace in by to take the time evolution into account.

outline.text: The change in the spatial coordinate
outline._note: If we want to derive exact solutions from the RH formulation, we do not have any knowledge of that appears in the jump condition . In order to address this issue, we introduce the change of the spatial coordinate We shall denote that is related to as follows, We apply the above change of variable to the reconstruction formula and obtain, From the above equation, we solve for to obtain where is obtained from the solution to the normalized RH problem, i.e., given , find sectionally meromorphic functions in such that and as in . We see that in is determined from solution to the RH problem without any knowledge of . The equation in fact corresponds to . By denoting and by definitions of the variable in and of in , we have We can avoid the integral expression above by noticing that, from , The argument of is written as since is determined on the variable. We will see that in fact is related to in .

In the following presentation, we choose , , and we denote Solving for in and in , we find that and In order to solve for the original variable , we solve for in and find that from One soliton solution is given by where and is found by an implicit equation . This coincides with one soliton in the original paper after the change of parameter because of our Lax pair with opposite sign for .
For this moment, it is convenient to use the variable . The denominator is denoted as We see that The case corresponds to smooth soliton solution.
On the other hand, it is easy to verify that, if , when For such value of , we have .
It appears that there are three distinguished cases , , and , according to the number of singularities of . For these three cases, behaves differently. We express as The range of can be read off from the above equation , that is, For convenience, we use the notation in to get Since , the slope of the function at is positive when , zero when , and negative when . The behaviors of differs with respect to these three cases.
The above Figure shows three different curves, as expected. The case gives whose slope is finite for all . The case gives whose slope is vertical at a point. The case gives which is multi-valued on some interval of .
In the following, we give soliton solutions for three different cases.

outline.text: the cases and (smooth soliton and bursting soliton)
outline._note:
The corresponding soliton solutions with in Figure \[fig1\] for and are shown in the following.
The maximum hight of the bursting soliton above is infinity. We emphasize that the bursting point corresponds to the value of for such that the slope of is vertical. This is easily seen from where is exactly the denominator of the one soliton . This implies that the shift by is very fast in the neighborhood of the singularity of the function for the case . The type of singularity of is an essential singularity, but because of the shift by , is in fact integrable. It may be of our interest to check the first conserved quantity: where in the second inequality we used the change of variable since we know from . We see that the first conserved quantity for one soliton solution is free of .

In Subsection \[smooth-bursting\], we considered two types of one soliton solutions that are smooth and bursting solitons. In this Section, we focus solely on two soliton solution with the following chosen parameters for in , and where we will fix values of and later on. In Subsection \[smooth-bursting\], corresponds to a bursting soliton and corresponds to a smooth soliton if .

outline.text: the case of (Two soliton solution with smooth and bursting peaks)
outline._note:
We first consider the case of in . In this case, we simply find that two soliton found in consists of a bursting soliton and a smooth soliton as shown in the following Figure, showing that the small peak bypasses the bursting peak as time increases.
The distance between two peaks increases as time increases, since the smaller peak moves faster.

outline.text: the case of and (Blowup soliton solution)
outline._note:
Next, we consider the case of and in . The corresponding soliton solution is found in .
We observe that the highest peak of at increases rapidly as time increases, as shown in the case of . In what follows, we will show that THE ABOVE SOLUTION BLOWS UP IN A FINITE TIME.
In order to show blowup, we are concerned with the denominator of in , i.e., Clearly, if , then . If is infinity, then there must be a point such that is infinity as well. We shall focus on the quantity .
The explicit expression of is lengthy, but we shall record it here, with (denote and )
We shall study it along the certain characteristic coordinate. The suitable choice comes from the observation that the first three terms in cancel to zero if and only if . Clearly, grows faster than . Therefore, we find that While the above does not still imply the finite time blowup, it implies that there exists an infinite peak along the characteristic at .
In order to conclude a finite-time blowup, we show the following Figure.
We find that the first zero of occurs at This implies that is the time when the infinite peak intersects with the characteristic line on the - coordinate. While the time is not likely to be the minimal blowup time, it still implies the existence of finite time blowup.
